\nWorld Dance Day celebrated in Aurangab.description: On the occasion of the World Dance Day on April 29, the city witnessed a beautiful dance recital under SAMBHAV: A dance-tribute aiming to ‘Dance beyond physical barriers’ organised at MAHAGAMI, MGM. Under this social outreach activity of MAHAGAMI, a 15-day dance workshop for differently abled children was conducted from April 15 onwards. The initiative was aimed towards exploring and sharing the joy of the expression of dance and its vitality coupled with the fact that creative minds can be nurtured beautifully through dance movements. The performance of these special children from Svayam Siddha was choreographed by Gargi Malkani and Rupal Khedkar. This was followed by a special Odissi dance performance by Nityanand Das from Odisha who dances on only one feet. Nityanand presented traditional Odissi based on the theme Pangu Langhayate Giri. Speaking on the occasion, Parwati Dutta, director MAHAGAMI Gurukul, said, “It is a dance day for us every day as we have inculcated dance in our life and dedicated our life to it. For the past 18 years we have been celebrating World Dance Day with all our heart and excitement.” Spectators were left spell-bound with the performance and gave a standing ovation.Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Hoteliers resolve to share excess food w.description: AURANGABAD: Save Food Committee, Aurangabad, has succeeded in roping in several hoteliers in their endeavour to save food from hotels and restaurants that goes to waste and provide it to the needy. Anant Motale, a retired government official, who is among the Ann Wachwa Samiti (save food committee), said at a meeting, attended by at least 25 hoteliers and government officials, that the participants resolved to share food that they prepare in excess with NGOs working for distribution of food. The committee, which was formed about five years ago, works for save food campaign and has got several function halls, hotels and residents to share the excess food immediately after being prepared with the NGOs that distribute it among the needy. Addressing media persons, Anant Motale of Mission for Hunger Free City, said that recently the committee had a meeting with the help of the Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) and MSSIDC with the as many as 25 restaurant owners, particularly those who serve thalis, to ensure that food is not wasted. While referring to the Global Hunger Index related reports, Motale highlighted that every day, food for 200 crore people was being prepared in the country, out of which food meant for 100 crore people was thrown in the garbage. This eventually leaves at least 27 crore people hungry, he said. He also said that marriage functions are the places where food goes to waste. The government officials concerned have urged hotel owners to follow norms to avoid food wastage, said Motale, adding that hoteliers have agreed to cooperate and have decided to offer 10% discount to the customers per thali if they finish everything served. 74,000 names enrolled in Maharashtra\u20.description: MUMBAI: The PAC report for the year 2017-18, submitted to the state assembly on Wednesday, came out with the results of the inquiry the committee conducted into suspected cases on the basis of the CAG report for 2014-15. The committee's inquiry revealed that between 2010 and 2015, there were 963 registered children's homes in the state. These homes belong to the state government but are run by NGOs. Of these, 213 were shut in 2016 after the authorities found that the names of over 74,000 children were fake. In 2017, three more children's homes were shut by the state women and child development department, taking the total to 216. The action was taken after the state adopted a policy of rechecks and new registrations of children with biometric impression, Aadhar card number and personal identification. Most irregularities were found during the rechecks. Three of the homes that were derecognized were from Mumbai and the suburban district, while half -- 107 - were located in Beed, Nanded, Osmanabad, Latur and Parbhani in Marathwada. The rest were in Solapur, Satara, Pune, Ahmednagar and Nashik. The government not only stopped grants but also instructed the administrators of these homes to shift the children enrolled there to children's homes elsewhere. Atul Bhatkhalkar, a member of the PAC for the women and child development department, demanded that a thorough inquiry be conducted by a special investigation team (SIT) into the matter. "After the inquiry, the culprits should be punished," Bhatkhalkar said. The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act 2015, enforced from January 15, 2016, laid down norms for facilities for children. Besides this, the Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court in its judgment of June 2015 had observed that children's homes must be capable of taking care and giving protection to children housed there. Youth held with marijuana worth Rs 5.25.description: AURANGABAD: The traffic branch of Aurangabad rural police has nabbed an alleged drug peddler and seized high quality marijuana worth Rs 5.25 lakh from his four-wheeler. The suspect, identified as Shahrukh Asgar Khan (22), a resident of Harsul area in the city was nabbed near Kasabkheda with 18kg of marijuana, apart from a four-wheeler. Police said that traffic inspector Mukund Aghav was enforcing a drive against errant vehicles, when he spotted the four-wheeler with registration number MH-21-V-0945 speeding at a breakneck speed from Kasabkheda to Devgaon Rangari on Sunday noon. It was after chasing it for a while, intercepted it. The police grew suspicious after the accused readily agreed to pay all the fine being slapped on him and leave. They scanned his vehicle to find nine packets of marijuana weighing 18 kilos stashed in the car. Soon the material along with the car was seized and the accused was arrested, before handing over to Sillegaon police station, where an offence came to be registered against him. Make full use of wells on campus: Bamu V.description: AURANGABAD: Devanand Shinde, in-charge vice chancellor of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (Bamu), on Saturday asked the university administration to work out on the possibility of making use of several wells situated on the campus for university’s water requirement. Bamu, which is the oldest university in Maharashtra after Mumbai and Pune universities, has around 43 large ancient wells located in different parts of its sprawling 731-acre campus. Most of these wells serve as perennial water resources being located at the level of natural basin of groundwater formed at the bottom of small mountain range on which the campus is situated. Shinde, who is also the vice-chancellor of Shivaji University Kolhapur (SUK), was given the additional charge of Bamu after retirement of BA Chopade. Incidentally, Shinde was working at the chemical technology department of Bamu before being appointed vice-chancellor of SUK. Thus, he is well verse with the functioning of the university and its campus. Addressing the university officials and management council members during his felicitation programmme, Shinde said there is a need for the university to become self-reliant for its water needs. He also asked the administration to ensure that the wells are maintained and make proper arrangements are made for the use of waste water. The in-charge VC also asked the administration to ensure utilization of available water resources to the fullest. Registrar Sadhana Pande, management council members Shankar Ambhore, Phulchand Salampure, Sanjay Salunke, Rahul Maske, finance and accounts officer Rajendra Madke had earlier felicitated the vice-chancellor. “The vice-chancellor also discussed issues like admission process, vacant posts, facilities at university hotels as well as problems being faced by the students,” Sanjay Shinde, a senior university official, said. BJP strengthens base in district, Shiv S.description: AURANGABAD: The Shiv Sena, which was virtually pushed to the brink in Beed, received a boost on Sunday after its newest entrant, former Nationalist Congress Party strongman Jaidutta Kshirsgar, made his way into the state’s cabinet. It's also the first time in years a Shiv Sena leader out of Beed has secured a cabinet berth. The last time the party had this much influence in the region was when Suresh Navale held a minister of state rank back in 1995. Since then, the Sena has been unable to make any considerable progress in the district - eventually reduced to contesting just one seat (Beed city) out of six assembly constituencies. The Sena would contest from the Georai and Ashti seats too, but withdrew when the late BJP stalwart, Gopinath Munde, won negotiations with the party's leadership, Sena observers in Beed told TOI. Khsirsagar, who had much to the chagrin of NCP leaders supported the BJP's Beed nominee Pritam Munde prior to the Lok Sabha polls, enjoys good ties with the Gopinath Munde camp. He is also rumoured to have joined the Sena at the behest of BJP leadership as the Beed city constituency goes to the Sena’s account for the next assembly election if the Sena-BJP poll arrangement is worked out, party sources said. Insiders also ruled out the possibility of a clash between Kshirsagar and the BJP's Pankaja Munde, the rural development minister and Beed’s guardian minister. According to sources, the Sena would want Kshirsagar to expand the party's base in the district and beyond. Sources close to Khshirsgar said he is expected to lose votes from his Muslim and Dalit base. But he stands to get votes from the Sena-BJP catchment, they said, while citing his victory in the 2014 assembly polls in which he defeated Vinayak Mete, the Maratha leader who had contested on a BJP ticket, by a margin of 5,000 votes. News of Kshirsagar's appointment, however, has not gone down well with veteran Sena party workers. "We now have to work for the man we had fought against,’’ said a senior Sena leader in Beed. He added that the move has "demoralized" senior workers of the party. The Aurangabad district found representation in the form of BJP’s Atul Save, the Aurangabad East MLA, although state assembly speaker, Haribhau Bagade, also belongs to the district. Save’s appointment makes a difference as he is essentially a party worker, state BJP president, Shirish Boralkar, told TOI. "His elevation will strengthen the BJP's presence in the district. It would help the party in the next assembly and the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation elections,’’ Boralkar said. Local sources said Save's appointment would boost the morale of BJP workers in Aurangabad, where the party has been relying on the Shiv Sena, whose four-time MP Chandrakant Khaire lost to the All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen's Imtiyaz Jaleel in the Lok Sabha polls. "Khaire's loss underscores the fact that the Sena has been losing ground here," a source said. "Khaire, instead of introspection, has been blaming the BJP for his defeat. He suspects the BJP supported Harshvardhan Jadhav, an ex-Sena man and son-in-law of the party’s state unit president Raosaheb Danve (also the Union minister of food and civil supplies), to ensure his defeat. But that is not true. Khaire lost because of his bad performance,’’ another BJP leader said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Railways\u2019 most powerful diesel loco.description: AURANGABAD: The massive yet lightest 6,000 horsepower diesel locomotive WDG-6G, most powerful amongst those in use on Indian Railways, is all set to debut on Vikarabad-Parli section of the South Central Railway (SCR). “Built by the General Electric (GE), in United States, the WDG-6G locomotive will offer a range of benefits including increase in carrying capacity of trains. Also, it is the first emission-compliant locomotive keeping in with the international standards,” chief public relations officer of SCR Ch Rakesh said on Tuesday. “The WDG-6G locomotive is ready to undergo Confirmatory Oscilograph Car Run (CDCR) trials before joining the fleet of locomotives of Indian Railways. It will be soon put on trials on the Vikarabad-Parli section of SCR soon,” he said, adding that the carrying capacity of a freight train rake will significantly increase due to the latest locomotive. For Indian Railways, the high powered locomotives convey the priority to optimize movement of freight traffic to meet ever-increasing demands and at the same time enhance revenue generation for the organisation. “The new breed of WDG-6G diesel locomotives will play a significant role in the plans of Indian Railways, which is undergoing a positive transformational phase to bolster its transportation capabilities. The key features of the most powerful workhorse to join the stables of Indian Railways include the incorporation of the latest technology into its system,” Rakesh said. The locomotive is UIC 1 emission compliant, the first of its kind in India when it comes to the international standards. Elaborating upon the technical specifications, SCR authorities said the latest loco is based on GE’s evolution series and is fitted with a 16-cylinder V-16 Evolution series engine, a four-stroke fully turbocharged and inter-cooled machine. “In tune with the priority to address issues concerning environmental adaptability the locomotive sports an electronic fuel injection system for higher fuel efficiency and lower emissions as compared to any other diesel locomotives in use on Indian Railways,” a SCR official said. Seminars on consumer rights and financia.description: AURANGABAD: Students studying in colleges under the jurisdiction of the state Directorate of Technical Education (DTE) will soon have an opportunity to attend a guidance seminar on consumer rights and financial literacy. In response to an appeal from the Consumer Guidance Society of India (CGSI), an NGO in the the consumer sector, the DTE has allowed such seminars across all colleges coming under its jurisdiction, including those from Marathwada. In the latest directive, the DTE has asked colleges to facilitate the desired seminars during the academic year 2019-20 by coordinating with the CGSI. “The CGSI is a pioneer non-profit organisation, which was founded in 1966 and works for the protection of interests of consumers. It has conducted many workshops and seminars to educate consumers and will be holding similar events in colleges from Maharashtra during the upcoming academic year,” a senior DTE official said. ‘How to manage money and be a smart investor’ will be the theme of the seminars, which will focus on the concept of consumer activity, consumer compliant redressal and the Consumer Protection Act, among other areas. The guidance seminar is scheduled to have a session each on the financial market, fundamentals of the stock market and essential qualities of a prudent investor. “As told by CGSI authorities, the seminars will cut through jargons and explain concepts and strategies through stories. The workshop will be strictly held on a non-profit basis and no selling of any financial product will take place during these sessions,” DTE authorities said, adding that students will benefit immensely from the workshop as they’d become finance-savvy at a young age. The CGSI will be represented by industry experts during the seminar and their fees will be borne by it only and colleges will have no related liabilities, it was said. Priyanka Gandhi.description: RAE BARELI: In her scathing attack on BJP and Modi government, Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi said that Congress doesn't need any certificate from anyone to prove its nationalist feelings. "Ye brashtachar ki baat karnewale sabse bade brashta hain… kaam ki baat karte hain magar sabse bade nikamme hain… dharma ki baat karne wale sabse bada adharm kar rahe hain - dharm ka istemal kar rahe hain… saheedon ka istemal kar rahe hain - sirf rajinit ke liye (They are talking of acting against corruption but are corrupt themselves… they talk of work but are good for nothing… they talk of dharma (read duties) but indulge in adharma by defying its norms - they use religion and martyrs for political interests)," Priyanka stated in her closed door meeting with cadres on Thursday. The Congress leader hit out at BJP's strategy of playing the nationalist card. "We are Congress… we launched the freedom movement… gave our blood and sweat… braved British atrocities … we don't need any certificate to prove our nationalist feelings especially from the ones who apologised to the British at that time", asserted Priyanka, urging the workers to go to every household in their area and meet every voter. She directed the workers to apprise the voters that the 2019 Lok Sabha election was as important as the freedom movement. Infusing energy in them she said, "Don't be afraid of anything as this is a weak government. Only a weak government curbs the voice of the people, which is a crime in democracy." Priyanka asked the workers to stand up for their leader whose only dream is the progress of India and its people. "Rahul thinks of the people without any vested interest," Priyanka said citing the example of her conversation with Rahul on the issue of using self-help group women for campaigning. "When I proposed to him this idea, he simply denied… saying that I created the SHGs to empower women, not use them in any way," Priyanka said quoting her brother. The Congress general secretary told the workers that she was working on mission 2022. "We will, with your support, form the government in 2022. And once we come, we will stay here for long on the basis of our hard work," she said adding that the hard-workers would be adequately rewarded. HC directs government not to transfer of.description: AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court on Monday directed the state government not to transfer the officer inquiring into the irregularities allegedly committed by three officials in appointing a contractor and eventually causing financial loss to the civic administration. Vikas Yedke, an MIM corporator, had approached the high court seeking directions to the government to institute an inquiry into the role of the officers and appropriate action against them. On Monday, deputy secretary of the urban development department, filed an affidavit informing the court that the officer inquiring into the conduct of the civic engineers had been transferred and that due to engagements involving the state budget session, the process was being delayed. The deputy secretary also informed the court that inquiry would be conducted on July 4. The matter came up for hearing before the bench comprising Justice Prasanna B Warale and Justice R G Agachat, when B L Sagar Killarikar, the lawyer representing the petitioner, pointed out to the court that the inquiry officer was changed without any reason. The bench directed the government not to change the newly-appointed inquiry officer till the completion of the inquiry. The court directed that the new inquiry officer should conduct inquiry within six months and the report be submitted to the court. The government had in 2016 sanctioned Rs 24.33 crore special fund for improvement of the roads to Aurangabad Municipal corporation (AMC). The works were to be conducted under observation and supervision of a three-member committee comprising divisional commissioner, the district collector and the municipal commissioner. Despite this, the civic engineers allegedly connived to ensure that only one company got the work and made changes in the process violating the norms, the petition alleged. The petitioner had made representations to various authorities. He approached the high court through lawyers Killarikar and N T Tribhuwan when he failed to get response from other authorities. Following the high court directions, two inquiries were ordered into the work — one by divisional commissioner and the other by principal secretary of urban development department. Both the inquiries indicted three civic officials for causing a loss of about Rs 1.67 crore to the civic body. The then municipal commissioner, Omprakash Bakoria, had initiated a departmental inquiry, but the general body didn’t give permission and subsequently petitioner approached the high court. Again, following high court directions D M Muglikar, the then civic body chief, appointed a regional inquiry officer to conduct the department inquiry. But this officer was having equivalent grade of the officials facing probe. Yedke then had then filed a civil application through Killarikar and Tribhwan pointing out that primary inquiry was conducted by an IAS officer of the principal secretary rank, therefore inquiry officer should be of the rank of secretary. Considering the arguments, bench then comprising Justices S S Shinde and R G Avachat had observed “in our opinion it may not be proper to entrust the inquiry of erring officers with the regional inquiry officer, Aurangabad who is not higher in rank. In our opinion, no prejudice would be caused to the delinquents if the inquiry is conducted by the inquiry officer not below the rank of the joint secretary.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Women artists shine at an exhibition hel.description: It was a delight for art lovers of Aurangabad as they came under one roof when eight female artists displayed their work at the recently held exhibition in the city. Held at Malti Art Gallery, near Kalda corner of Aurangabad, the artists –Manisha Kurekar, Gauri Narsapur, Vjayaya Paturkar, Sharda Uttarwar, Rekha Jakhete, Shalda Mendhekar, Mamta Kulkarni and Megha Padhyay created art of different medium on the canvas. Th exhibition titled –Thousand Shades of Her, saw paintings of various types. Though most of them used acrylic colours as their medium, each painting had a different style to it. Modern art got a touch of traditional Madhubani art and miniature touch, Gujrat's Mad Art and various other types of paintings were at display at the exhibition. Kunal Lahariya and Lata Mule were chief guests for the evening. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Tamil Nadu Elections.description: Voting for Lok Sabha elections 2019 in Tamil Nadu will take place in a single phase on April 18 as per the notification issued by the Election Commission of India. The counting of votes will take place on May 23. | Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesThe four-cornered contest for the 39 Lok Sabha seats features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). Out of the 39 seats in the state, seven Lok Sabha seats are reserved for SC. The constituencies reserved for SC candidates are Thiruvallur, Kancheepuram, Villupuram, Nilgiris, Chidambaram, Nagapattinam and Tenkasi in Tamil Nadu. | Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesIn the last Lok Sabha polls, AIADMK had a vote share of 44.3 per cent by winning 37 seats. BJP had a vote share of 5.5 per cent by winning just 1 seat, while NDA managed to win two seats with a vote share of 18.5 per cent PMK won one seat and had a vote share of 4.4 per cent. BJP (NDA) had an alliance with PMK. DMK was not able to win on any seat in the last Lok Sabha polls. In Lok Sabha elections 2019, DMK is contesting on 20 seats, while the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Chamki fever.description: MUZAFFARPUR: The toll in the outbreak of Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES) in Bihar rose to 114 on Wednesday with seven more deaths in the endemic zone even as reports came in of children being admitted with similar symptoms in other districts like Samastipur, Banka and Vaishali. Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur, where most of the patients have been undergoing treatment since the disease spread, struggled to handle the spate of new admissions with its limited infrastructure. Sources at the hospital said the stream of high-profile visitors, including the chief minister and the Union health minister, was adding to the chaos. The scarcity of beds and doctors continued even as the Bihar State Health Society issued a list of 15 doctors, technicians and nurses deputed by the Union health ministry to assist at the hospital. "All 637 beds, including 30 in the paediatric ICUs, are occupied. We have had to put two kids on one bed to accommodate more children," SKMCH superintendent Sunil Kumar Shahi said. He admitted that there was a shortage of senior resident doctors in every department. "Though there is a shortage, it is inhuman to turn away patients just because we cannot accommodate them. Many of them have come from far-flung villages of north Bihar. Around 40 to 50 new cases of AES have been coming every day, but our resources are very limited." To ease the crisis, a makeshift paediatric ICU with 20 beds and four new ACs was set up on Wednesday. But frequent power cuts hampered the efforts. The Hhospital authorities said 154 children were undergoing treatment for AES at three paediatric ICUs with 10 beds each. In Vaishali, civil surgeon ID Ranjan said 15 suspected cases of AES had been reported from Hajipur. "Several kids have died in the villages there. Some have died in the referral hospital before being diagnosed. Their relatives say they had high fever and convulsions, among other symptoms indicative of AES." At least three of seven infants with AES symptoms admitted to the Sadar hospital in Samastipur were referred to the SKMCH. One of them died on the way. But civil surgeon Siyaram Mishra denied that any AES patient had been admitted at the Sadar hospital. In Banka district, the death of a two-year-old in a village in Katoria block has caused alarm. Muzaffarpur DM Alok Ranjan Ghosh has cancelled the leave of all government employees in the district. "The number of children admitted with AES symptoms since June 1 has gone up to 5,530. Till Wednesday, 187 kids were discharged after treatment while 101 of them are still under the care of the two main medical institutions in the district. The condition of 24 children is critical. All of them are on ventilators," Ghosh said. "A massive awareness campaign has started in all blocks with the help of Jiveeka associates and aanganwadi sevikas and sahayeekas. Executive magistrates have been deployed in every block to monitor the awareness programme, apart from keeping a close vigil on the patients with AES." Neighbouring Ranchi is also in the grip of an AES scare, with anxious parents taking their children to hospitals at the slightest hint of any symptom associated with the disease. Nisha Devi, a mother of two daughters aged six and four, said: "Both my daughters have been running a fever for two days. Though the paediatrician I visited advised rest and prescribed a few medicines, I insisted on complete blood tests for both to rule out AES." Standing in a line with his four-year-old daughter at Ranchi Sadar Hospital, Jagatram, a worker in an electronics shop, looked and sounded worried. "I brought her here because she was running a temperature all night. With so many kids dying in Bihar, I cannot take any risk," said the father of two. District civil surgeon BV Prasad told TOI that the Ranchi administration would release guidelines for AES awareness to quell the panic and confusion. "It is a good thing that parents are alert. Although this means long queues in the paediatric departments, chances of a case going undetected are minimised. We will be releasing a communique informing people about AES and its symptoms. Fever, vomiting and convulsions - all three symptoms are generally connected with AES and parents of small kids experiencing even one of those should consult a doctor," he said. Times ViewLittle children dying or suffering permanent brain damage is always a human tragedy, but when official apathy and neglect contirbute to it, that is criminal dereliction of duty. Bihar has seen these deaths happen year after year even if the numbers have in one year gone down and in another shoot up. Muzaffarpur has been the epicenter. Given those facts, it is just inexcusable that the government has failed so miserably in ensuring the public health set-up is equipped to cope. Grand schemes count for little if they are of no help to poor families losing their little ones. Of course, tackling this disease needs more than just good PHCs or hospitals. As long as malnutrition is rampant, the problem will remain. To root it out, therefore, adequate nutrition is the first step. But that does not preclude effective medical intervention to ensure that the loss of lives is kept to the minimum if not eliminated altogether.(With inputs from Debjani Chakraborty in Ranchi)Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Section of teachers stage protest.description: AURANGABAD: Coinciding with the reopening of schools after the summer vacation, a section of teachers from some unaided schools protested to highlight their demands, including for benefits of the old pension scheme, on Monday. The agitating teachers wore a black badge on their arms as a mark of protest because of the alleged government apathy towards their demands. The protest, however, did not affect the functioning of the schools. In a statement, the teachers have threatened to step up their protest. ‘After a symbolic protest on day one of the reopening of schools, we have decided to stage a demonstration at Mumbai in support of the different demands. The state government has been consistently turning a deaf ear to our demands, which is unacceptable’, according to the statement. The NCP-led Teachers Union, the Association of Progressive Members of Teaching and Non-teaching Staff, the National Teachers Union and the Action Committee of Urdu Schools were among the organizations which extended their support towards Monday’s protest. It may be recalled that the state government, during November 2001, had decided to allow the opening of new schools as “permanently unaided institutions”. Following the decision, over 3,500 new schools came up across the state, which in due course, started demanding finical aid from the government. Giving up to the demand from these schools, the state government decided to remove the word “permanently” from its earlier policy of “permanently unaided institutions” during July 2009. After a gap of two years, the policy decision to release a grant-in-aid in instalments of 20% to eligible schools was taken in 2011, followed by a revision of the norms for deciding eligible schools in July 2013. It was the Union cabinet decision taken during August 2016 that actually pushed the process of release of grant-in-aid for unaided schools. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

GMCH conducts procedure to detect non-pa.description: AURANGABAD: The Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) here became the first government medical college in state to have conducted an advanced preoperative process called stereotactic hookwire localisation to identify non-palpable cancer. The procedure was carried out as part of a breast imaging course held by the college. A one-day continuing medical education conference was also held as part of the breast imaging course. As many as 180 delegates, including radiologists, pathologists, surgeons and PG radiology and surgery students from Aurangabad, Nanded, Hingoli, Jalgaon and other cities participated in the event. Varsha Rote Kaginalkar, professor and head of department radiology, GMCH, said that many a times cancers are not detected by sonography as they do not have mass. “The stereotactic hookwire localisation process under ultrasound was carried out by two faculties from Mumbai to identify a non-palpable cancer in a patient. The cancer was removed in a surgical procedure subsequently. The GMCH Aurangabad has all the setup required for carrying out the diagnostic process,” Kaginalkar said. In the workshop lectures were held on different subjects and hands-on training in ultrasound guided core needle biopsy on chicken breasts was given. The national faculty for the programme incuded Bijal Jankharia, consultant, Picture This by Jankharia, Mumbai and Sabita Desai, consultant, Breach Candy Hospital, Mumbai. AMC eyes achieving ODF++ tag before Octo.description: AURANGABAD: As part of the Swachh Bharat Urban programme, all cities in the state, including Aurangabad, are required to ensure proper functioning of their public and community toilets to qualify as open defecation free (ODF) city. Based on whether the cities have only toilets or they have both toilets as well as sewage treatment plants within 20km radius, cities will get the ODF+ or the ODF++ tag. Speaking to TOI, deputy secretary at the state government’s urban development department, Sudhakar Bobade said that the cities had declared details about the number of applications filed for individual household latrine (IHHL) and the number of IHHLs constructed on the Swachh Bharat Mission portal. “The cities are expected to bridge the gap between the number of applications filed and the toilets constructed by June 30,” said Bobade. He further said that the urban local bodies (ULBs) had to ensure that the community and public toilets in the city were in good shape. First, the ULBs should ensure that the existing toilets are repaired and have light, water and are properly cleaned. The cities applying for ODF+ should have atleast 10% and those applying for ODF++ should have atleast 25% toilets with additional facilities like exhaust fan, vending machines and other amenities. “There will be a three phase inspection for ODF+ and ODF++ in which the municipal commissioner will have to make a self-declaration about the status of public and community toilets. After this, the divisional coordinator of Swachh Bharat will inspect and finally a third party inspection by Delhi based QCI will be conducted,” said Bobade. He said that Aurangabad would have to meet ODF++ requirements before October 2 i.e. the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi. Vijaya Ghadge, who is overseeing the ODF status of the city, said that AMC would be repairing around 30 existing public toilets and constructing 25 new ones. Lok Sabha Poll 2019.description: LUCKNOW: With electioneering for the 2019 Lok Sabha polls gaining steam in Uttar Pradesh, political leaders are increasingly resorting to personal attacks on their adversaries. If the maverick BJP MLA from Bairia, Surendra Singh hit the headlines for his remarks against BSP supremo Mayawati, Uttar Pradesh cabinet minister Shrikant Sharma hit a new low by making indecent comments on Congress chief Rahul Gandhi. The Bairia MLA had said Mayawati gets facials done and her hair coloured even though she is 60-years-old. He also reportedly made offensive remarks against UPA chairperson Sonia Gandhi and Haryanvi singer-dancer Sapna Chaudhary, evoking widespread criticism from political parties and social media users. A media agency quoted him as saying that both Sonia Gandhi and Sapna Chaudhary used to work as dancers. "Rahul's mother (Sonia Gandhi) was also in the same profession in Italy and his father made her his own. He (Rahul Gandhi) should also take the family tradition forward and make Sapna his own," the MLA said. The BJP legislator, who is known for his controversial statements, had earlier termed Rahul Gandhi and his sister Priyanka Gandhi Vadra "Ravana and Shurpanakha", and accused Mayawati of "murdering" a woman's dignity by joining hands with one-time arch rival Samajwadi Party. UP Power Minister Shrikant Sharma stirred up a hornet's nest with his tweet terming the Congress president a "coward and impotent". The comments triggered a war of words between the two parties as well as on social media platform. Firebrand Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath also finds mention in the list of leaders accused of making personal remarks against political rivals. He recently termed Congress candidate from Saharanpur, Imran Masood, the son-in-law of Jaish-e-Mohammed chief Azhar Masood. Addressing a rally in Saharanpur on Sunday, Adityanath said, "The son-in-law of Azhar Masood has entered the constituency and he speaks the language of the terror mastermind. "You people have to ensure that the person who speaks the language of Azhar Masood is defeated in the Lok Sabha elections," he said while seeking votes for BJP candidate from Saharanpur, Raghav Lakhanpal. Union minister and BJP MP Mahesh Sharma referred to Rahul Gandhi as 'Pappu' and his sister Priyanka Gandhi as 'Pappu ki Pappi' during a poll campaign in Gautam Buddh Nagar. Rahul Gandhi has often been mocked by the BJP and his opposition as 'Pappu', a colloquial sneer. "Pappu kehta hai main prime minister banunga Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu.. aur ab 'Pappu ki Pappi' bhi aa gayi hai. Wo Priyanka kya pehle hamare desh ki beti nahi thi kya, Congress ki beti nahi thi kya, aage nahi rahegi kya? kya naya leke aayi hai?" the minister told a crowd of his supporters on March 16. The quotes loosely translate to "Pappu says he wants to become prime minister. Mayawati, Akhilesh Yadav, Pappu ... and now 'Pappu's Pappi' has also arrived. Wasn't Priyanka already a daughter of this nation, a daughter of the Congress? And would she not remain so in future? What new has she brought in?"
